threads.author: l33tbunni
threads.content: This tracks with lining up some of the bytes I was doing in the firmware update blob against the flash dump from seeigecannon, it matches a wholllle lot more

threads.author: l33tbunni
threads.content: First half of the chip matches perfectly. Flash is busted

threads.author: l33tbunni
threads.content: or got a bad write

threads.author: l33tbunni
threads.content: nope, all in one address space, JEDEC compatible NOR flash

threads.author: l33tbunni
threads.content: I've dumped it about 20 times in total

threads.author: l33tbunni
threads.content: almost all of them have ~500 byte differences between them, all in the range of 0x7c000 - 0x7cfff which is why I thought just that one 4k sector was hosed.

threads.author: l33tbunni
threads.content: And the fact that I can read more than a sector and that is valid data from 0x0 till that 0x7c000 sector start, and that is also more than the full page of that chip, I think the flash itself underneath failed rather than some controller IC failure

threads.author: l33tbunni
threads.content: yeah, I've never seen flash fail in this way

threads.author: l33tbunni
threads.content: I spent a good couple of hours trying to dump the chip with different devices too, they all got roughly the same data, aside from that chunk of bytes that were randomish every read

threads.author: l33tbunni
threads.content: I only have the one known good dump. But yeah, I'm going to do some testing on it and see what it does and how it behaves. Need to read the OTP data off it too

threads.author: l33tbunni
threads.content: Its not very old, year or two. I think it got a botched firmware update

threads.author: l33tbunni
threads.content: Thats the only reason I can think of a few pages of good data, then some sector that didn't get a clean erase/write in a state of nomansland when reading the flash cell, then the rest of the data garbage

threads.author: l33tbunni
threads.content: I spent a good couple of hours trying to dump the chip with different devices too, they all got roughly the same data, aside from that chunk of bytes that were randomish every read

threads.author: l33tbunni
threads.content: I only have the one known good dump. But yeah, I'm going to do some testing on it and see what it does and how it behaves. Need to read the OTP data off it too

threads.author: l33tbunni
threads.content: Its not very old, year or two. I think it got a botched firmware update

threads.author: l33tbunni
threads.content: Thats the only reason I can think of a few pages of good data, then some sector that didn't get a clean erase/write in a state of nomansland when reading the flash cell, then the rest of the data garbage

threads.author: l33tbunni
threads.content:
Its aliiiivveeee!

```
S - Core 0 Frequency, 800 MHz


U-Boot 2016.01 [UniFi,v1.0.25.152] (Feb 23 2023 - 15:40:51 -0800)

DRAM:  smem ram ptable found: ver: 1 len: 4
```

threads.author: l33tbunni
threads.content: it booted linux, need to do a reset, adopt, update, and see how that goes

threads.author: l33tbunni
threads.content: hmm, doing a reset put it in TFTP recovery mode. So, eMMC must have had some incomplete update as well

threads.author: tawnos
threads.content: Lol, it was a progression of finding parts. Had some low power switching mosfets that couldn't handle sustained current, added relays to see if they could handle that, but were still underpowered, dug through parts and found high power mosfets. way overkill but whatever, now I need to determine if pin 10 is fried ðŸ˜…

threads.author: tawnos
threads.content: I already snipped out the relays

threads.author: tawnos
threads.content: Pin 10 isn't changing from 0 to 5v, even though 9 and 11 are. Also think I lost the sketch, but it's easy enough to recreate

threads.author: tawnos
threads.content: Also pretty sure I can take off the 5v psu and power the trinket from 12v

threads.author: tawnos
threads.content: Up to 16v power input, nice
